sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using QR decomposition
message_1:
Solve the system of linear equations using QR decomposition:

3x + 2y - z = 6

x - y + 4z = -7

2x + 3y - 5z = -3
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using QR decomposition, we first need to rewrite the system in the matrix form Ax = b, where A is the matrix of coefficients, x is the column vector of variables, and b is the column vector of constants.

The given system can be written as:

A = | 3  2 -1 |
    | 1 -1  4 |
    | 2  3 -5 |

x = | x |
    | y |
    | z |

b = |  6  |
    | -7  |
    | -3  |

Now, we will perform QR decomposition on matrix A. QR decomposition is a method of decomposing a matrix A into an orthogonal matrix Q and an upper triangular matrix R such that A = QR.

Using the Gram-Schmidt process, we can find the orthogonal matrix Q and the upper triangular matrix R.

1. Find the orthonormal basis for A:

u1 = a1 = (3, 1, 2)
e1 = u1 / ||u1|| = (3, 1, 2) / sqrt(14) = (3/sqrt(14), 1/sqrt(14), 2/sqrt(14))

u2 = a2 - proj(a2, e1) = (2, -1, 3) - ((2, -1, 3)·e1)e1 = (2, -1, 3) - (11/14)(3, 1, 2)
u2 = (-1/14, -3/14, 17/14)
e2 = u2 / ||u2|| = (-1/14, -3/14, 17/14) / sqrt(59/196) = (-2/sqrt(59), -6/sqrt(59), 34/sqrt(59))

u3 = a3 - proj(a3, e1) - proj(a3, e2) = (-1, 4, -5) - ((-1, 4, -5)·e1)e1 - ((-1, 4, -5)·e2)e2
u3 = (-1, 4, -5) - (1/14)(3, 1, 2) - (20/59)(-2, -6, 34)
u3 = (-1/2, 1/2, -1/2)
e3 = u3 / ||u3|| = (-1/2, 1/2, -1/2) / sqrt(3/4) = (-1/sqrt(3), 1/sqrt(3), -1/sqrt(3))

2. Form the orthogonal matrix Q and the upper triangular matrix R:

Q = |  3/sqrt(14)  -2/sqrt(59)  -1/sqrt(3) |
    |  1/sqrt(14)  -6/sqrt(59)   1/sqrt(3) |
    |  2/sqrt(14)  34/sqrt(59)  -1/sqrt(3) |

R = | ||a1||  a2·e1  a3·e1 | = | sqrt(14)  11/14  1/14  |
    |   0     ||u2||  a3·e2 |   |   0     sqrt(59/14) 20/59 |
    |   0       0    ||u3|| |   |   0       0     sqrt(3/4) |

3. Solve the system Rx = Q^Tb:

Q^T = |  3/sqrt(14)   1/sqrt(14)   2/sqrt(14) |
      | -2/sqrt(59)  -6/sqrt(59)  34/sqrt(59) |
      | -1/sqrt(3)    1/sqrt(3)   -1/sqrt(3) |

Q^Tb = |  3/sqrt(14)*6 + 1/sqrt(14)*(-7) + 2/sqrt(14)*(-3) |
        | -2/sqrt(59)*6 - 6/sqrt(59)*(-7) + 34/sqrt(59)*(-3) |
        | -1/sqrt(3)*6 + 1/sqrt(3)*(-7) - 1/sqrt(3)*(-3) |

Q^Tb = |  sqrt(14)  |
        | 20/sqrt(59) |
        | -sqrt(3/4)  |

Now, we can solve the system Rx = Q^Tb using back-substitution:

z = -sqrt(3/4) / sqrt(3/4) = -1

y = (20/sqrt(59) - 20/59*(-1)) / sqrt(59/14) = 1

x = (sqrt(14) - 11/14*1 - 1/14*(-1)) / sqrt(14) = 2

So, the solution to the system of linear equations is x = 2, y = 1, and z = -1.
